title: Acid-Base Titration
objective: To determine the concentration of a given acid using a standard alkali.

procedure.instruction: Rinse the burette with NaOH solution to ensure accuracy.
Fill the burette with NaOH solution and record the initial reading.
Measure exactly 25ml of HCl solution using a pipette into a clean conical flask.
Add 2-3 drops of phenolphthalein indicator to the HCl solution.
Slowly add NaOH from the burette while swirling the flask. Watch for the color change from colorless to pale pink.
Record the final burette reading and calculate the volume of NaOH used.
Repeat the titration at least two more times to ensure accuracy.

safetyNotes: Wear gloves and goggles at all times. Handle acids and bases with care. Work in a well-ventilated area.

title: Standard Enthalpy of Combustion
objective: To determine the enthalpy change of combustion of ethanol using calorimetry.

procedure.instruction: Set up the calorimeter and measure 100ml of water into the copper can.
Record the initial temperature of the water.
Place the spirit burner with ethanol under the copper can and light it.
Allow the ethanol to burn until the temperature rises by approximately 20°C.
Record the final temperature and the mass of ethanol burned.
Calculate the enthalpy change using q = mcΔT.

safetyNotes: Keep flammable materials away from open flame. Use proper ventilation. Handle hot equipment with tongs.

title: Redox Titration: Potassium Permanganate with Oxalic Acid
objective: To determine the concentration of oxalic acid solution using potassium permanganate as a self-indicator in redox titration.

procedure.instruction: Prepare a standard solution of potassium permanganate (0.1M) in a clean beaker.
Rinse the burette with KMnO₄ solution and fill it up to the zero mark.
Pipette 25ml of oxalic acid solution into a clean conical flask.
Add 20ml of dilute sulfuric acid to the oxalic acid solution.
Heat the mixture to about 60-70°C using a water bath.
Titrate the hot solution with KMnO₄ solution, swirling continuously until a permanent pale pink color appears.
Record the burette reading and repeat the titration at least two more times for accuracy.

safetyNotes: Wear protective gloves and goggles. Handle KMnO₄ carefully as it can stain. Sulfuric acid is corrosive - handle with care. Work in a well-ventilated area.

title: Rate of Reaction: Sodium Thiosulfate and Hydrochloric Acid
objective: To investigate how the concentration of reactants affects the rate of reaction between sodium thiosulfate and hydrochloric acid.

procedure.instruction: Place a cross-marked paper under a clean conical flask.
Measure 50ml of sodium thiosulfate solution (0.1M) and pour it into the flask.
Measure 5ml of hydrochloric acid (2M) in a separate measuring cylinder.
Add the HCl to the flask and immediately start the stopwatch.
Observe the cross through the solution and stop the timer when the cross is no longer visible.
Record the time taken for the reaction to complete.
Repeat the experiment with different concentrations of sodium thiosulfate (0.08M, 0.06M, 0.04M, 0.02M) while keeping HCl concentration constant.
Calculate the rate of reaction (1/time) for each concentration and plot a graph.

safetyNotes: Wear safety goggles and lab coat. Handle hydrochloric acid with care. Sulfur dioxide gas is produced - ensure good ventilation. Do not inhale the fumes.

title: Electrolysis of Water
objective: To demonstrate the decomposition of water into hydrogen and oxygen gases using electrolysis and verify the 2:1 ratio of gases produced.

procedure.instruction: Set up the Hoffman voltameter apparatus with graphite electrodes.
Fill the voltameter with dilute sulfuric acid solution (about 10% by volume) to act as an electrolyte.
Connect the electrodes to a DC power supply (6-12V) with the positive terminal to the anode and negative to the cathode.
Switch on the power supply and observe gas bubbles forming at both electrodes.
Allow the electrolysis to proceed for 5-10 minutes and observe the volume of gas collected in each arm.
Measure the volume of gas in each tube and record the ratio.
Test the gas in the cathode tube (hydrogen) with a burning splint - it should produce a 'pop' sound.
Test the gas in the anode tube (oxygen) with a glowing splint - it should relight.

safetyNotes: Wear safety goggles. Hydrogen gas is highly flammable - keep away from open flames. Ensure proper ventilation. Handle sulfuric acid with care. Disconnect power supply when not in use.

title: Preparation of Soap (Saponification)
objective: To prepare soap from vegetable oil using the saponification reaction with sodium hydroxide and understand the chemistry of soap formation.

procedure.instruction: Measure 100ml of vegetable oil and pour it into a clean beaker.
Prepare a solution of 10g NaOH in 30ml of distilled water (handle with care - exothermic reaction).
Add 50ml of ethanol to the oil to help dissolve it.
Heat the oil-ethanol mixture to about 50-60°C on a hot plate.
Slowly add the NaOH solution to the warm oil mixture while stirring continuously.
Continue heating and stirring for 20-30 minutes until the mixture becomes thick and homogeneous (soap formation).
Add saturated sodium chloride solution to precipitate the soap (salting out).
Filter the soap using filter paper and wash it with cold water.
Allow the soap to dry and observe its properties.

safetyNotes: Wear safety goggles, gloves, and lab coat. Sodium hydroxide is highly corrosive - handle with extreme care. Work in a well-ventilated area. Ethanol is flammable - keep away from open flames. Avoid contact with skin.

title: Determination of pH using Universal Indicator
objective: To determine the pH values of various household and laboratory solutions using universal indicator and create a pH scale reference.
materials: Various test solutions (lemon juice, vinegar, tap water, baking soda, soap solution, NaOH, HCl, etc.)

procedure.instruction: Label test tubes for each solution to be tested.
Pour approximately 5ml of each test solution into its labeled test tube.
Add 2-3 drops of universal indicator to each test tube.
Gently swirl each test tube to mix the indicator with the solution.
Observe the color change in each test tube.
Compare the colors with the pH color chart provided.
Record the pH value for each solution based on the color match.
Arrange the solutions in order from most acidic (lowest pH) to most basic (highest pH).
Create a pH scale diagram showing the position of each tested solution.

results.reactionEquation: Universal indicator changes color based on H⁺ ion concentration

safetyNotes: Wear safety goggles and gloves. Handle acids and bases with care. Do not taste any solutions. Work in a well-ventilated area. Wash hands after handling chemicals.
